This needs to be smarter:
 - must be an AIO-SX
 - check the tier that the stor is in, there must be stors with function STOR_FUNCTION_OSD > 1 (avoids a 1 journal + 1 OSD false positive)
 - replication factor must be > 1 (can't delete if the replication factor is 1 or there will be data loss)
Code seems fine. The only other improvement would be to provide an enhanced error message when one of the satisfy conditions aren't met so the end user knows what prevented the deletion.

nova/objects/instance_numa.py.message:
The original logic is needlessly complex, which makes the patch needlessly complex as well.

We need to set cell.pcpuset in all cases, the question is, what do we set it to?

If the policy is DEDICATED, we set pcpuset = cpuset, and null out cpuset.

In all other cases, pcpuset = <empty set>

So why not just refactor the whole thing to:

  if len(cpuset) != 0 and cell.cpu_policy == obj_fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.DEDICATED:
    cell.pcpuset = cell.cpuset
    cell.cpuset = set()
  else:
    cell.pcpuset = set()

I think that covers everything, and is much more readable, no?

Sorry, I now realize this is basically exactly what you did, it's just formatted... weirdly. Unit tests are still -1 though ;)

Suggestion for the formatting:

  if (
    len(cell.cpuset) != 0
    and cell.cpu_policy == obj_fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.DEDICATED
  ):
    <stuff>

i think we did not do this to avoid do data migration of all numa instances on upgrade.
we only wanted to migrate pinned instances. the current codde assumed you would check if the pcpuset was set before using it rather then assuming it was initallised to an empty set.

i belive the correct convetion is to use 'pcpuset' in cell

this will correctly test if a filed in an ovo is set.
we avoid using hasattr for this by convention when dealing with ovos.

The idea, based in on [1], was to formululate an intentionally non-explicit version of Python so that the text is future-proof.

I also thought it's worth mentioning that k-a runs on Python 3, hence "3.x". This should be future proof for a good while. (AFAIK all k-a maintained releases run on Python 3).

Are you saying that I should write something like

"Python 3.6 (default in CentOS 8 Stream)
Python 3.8 (latest available; default in Ubuntu 20.04)"

?

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1880290/comments/2

I'd definitely like to avoid mentioning specific versions that we need to update.

We could include a general comment like the one you've added, followed by a more specific link to the governance page for the current release (using the release name variable you added)

I'd be fine with that variant
Let's say "supports default Python 3.x versions" and we are golden.

1) test Focal with 3.9
2) write in docs specific tested distros and versions (comes with text maintenance on each release)

By default if I check the file permissions for testfile it is set to nobody after mounting the nfs share

-rw-r--r--. 1 nobody nobody 0 Mar 10 09:14 /mnt/testfile

I can write into the file after changing the ownership. is this the expected behaviour for writing to the file?

You don't need to change the ownership. 
"nobody" owner is what we expect in this case.

You can simply do the following change:

test_data = "some data"
script = f"sudo cloud-init status -w;" \
         f"sudo ip add add {ip}/24 dev eth1;" \
         f"sudo ip link set eth1 up;" \
         f"sudo mount {mount_opt} {location[0]} /mnt || exit 1;" \
         f"df -h;" \
         f"sudo echo {test_data} | sudo tee /mnt/testfile || exit 2"

src/files/auto-retrofit.sh.message: What if the unit name doesn't contain `retrofit`? What if there are several units? Shouldn't the unit name be passed as an argument to this script? The code that creates the cronjob knows the unit name.

The cron job is set within the unit, moreover only on leader unit as we don't want the retrofitting process to run in parallel on multiple units. Please check src/lib/charm/openstack/octavia_diskimage_retrofit.py line and following. octavia-diskimage-retrofit is a subordinate charm - hence I think that there is no chance that there might be more than one running unit on a single container/machine.
And yes, under specific circumstances it is possible that the unit name has been overridden - I will fix this.
Wouldn't the entire implementation be easier if we were calling `juju run-action ...` instead? As there is already an action implemented.

Do you need to change the Fake NFVO server other than fixing the following patches?
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/831566

Again, have you tested negative test cases (for subscription, notification, and lcm operation) in the local environment to make sure multi-tenant LCM work correctly?

I understood, I misunderstand the subscription server and NFVO server are different.
Thank you very much.

Thanks for your answer, in my understanding as below, is it correct?
* negative test cases need different NFVO server for each tenant.
* but currently Tacker can't target different NFVO server for each tenant, therefore NFVO server design need to be changed.

Sorry for my lack of knowledge, I don't understand the first point, could you tell me why the same NFVO server is not good and you need another NFVO server?

The design was to dedicate a subscription notification server for each tenant to validate that these servers only receive notifications of VNF package or LCM operations performed by their respective tenants.

The NFVO server changes done in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/831566 introduce multiple instantiations of FakeServerManager class objects, which helps in executing positive test cases for multi-tenant policy.

In my understanding, in multi-tenant negative test cases, we might require dedicated NFVO servers (physical server) per tenant which could reject the upcoming requests if not for a particular tenant.

Whereas current implementation Zuul or local environment have 2 NFVO servers listening on localhost, without any port restriction on request. So it was difficult to test negative cases locally as well.

Therefore as suggested would test negative test cases in the upcoming cycle with the new NFVO server design.

Jim, since several of these depend on each other would you want to handle the WF +1s?
Thanks!
Will leave Jim to coordinate the WF+1 across the set of these. Thanks Jim.

The depends-ons should not be set to point to each other.  It should be done either as a chain with one at the root or all of them pointing at the same one ie. the root.  The root should have WF -1 on it, only being given the WF +1 once all of the others are WF +1.  The designer submitting this commit set for review should be managing the WF -1 on the root and setting up the dependency chain.  They should reach out to a core reviewer for the final WF +1 on the root once everything else is good to go in.

Looking at the depends-on here, it does look like a proper chain with https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/tools/+/831338 at the root.  That root should have WF -1 on it to prevent accidental merging before the others are ready.

ovs-dpdk currently has a problem with both OFED versions. I had file a defect
for it https://jira.wrs.com/browse/CGTS-32868.

I think it would be a good and relatively easy test to ensure that ovs-dpdk does not break in the interim with the new OFED.  I do not expect that it will, as we are already using an OFED beyond which the minimum is recommended for DPDK 18.11.  It should just be a case of running some commands if you have a lab available.  You would generally follow

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StarlingX/Docs_and_Infra/InstallationGuides/baremetal-AIO-Duplex

See section 'Configure Controller-0':

# Lock controller-0

system host-lock controller-0

# Create datanetworks if you don't have them already (system datanetwork-list)

system datanetwork-add physnet-0 vlan
system datanetwork-add physnet-1 vlan

# Configure the MLX interfaces as class 'data'

system host-if-modify -m 1500 -n data0 -c data controller-0 ${DATA0IFUUID}
system host-if-modify -m 1500 -n data1 -c data controller-1 ${DATA1IFUUID}

(The DATAXIFUUID would be MLX interfaces you can get via system host-if-list controller-0)

# Assign the MLX interfaces to the datanetworks

system interface-datanetwork-assign controller-0 ${DATA0IFUUID} physnet-0
system interface-datanetwork-assign controller-0 ${DATA1IFUUID} physnet-1

# Assign host-labels to enable the vswitch to start

system host-label-assign controller-0 openstack-control-plane=enabled
system host-label-assign controller-0 openstack-compute-node=enabled
system host-label-assign controller-0 openvswitch=enabled

# Set system vswitch type, 1G hugepages and at least one dedicated cpu on each socket dedicated to vswitch

system modify --vswitch_type ovs-dpdk
system host-memory-modify controller-0 0 -1G 2
system host-memory-modify controller-0 1 -1G 2
system host-cpu-modify -f vswitch -p0 1 controller-0
system host-cpu-modify -f vswitch -p1 1 controller-0

Unlock
system host-unlock controller-0

Feel free to contact me if you need clarification

one thing we need to keep in mind is that multiple port bindings are still optional in neutron so we have to also support the case where only a single port binding is used.

        * Puppet upgrade manifest will set a upgrade flag to dectet the upgrade workflow during unlocking first time.
    Step 2: When unlock controller-1 it runs puppet controller manifest.
        * Puppet controller manifest will take into account the upgrade flag created by upgrade manifest and remove the taint for controller-1
2. When execute system host-upgrade controller-0
    * Pods are going to be moved to controller-1 due to controller-1 will not containt taints configuration.
    * at this point when controller-0 get unlock state, it will have taint set.
3. When execute system upgrade-activation upgrade script will upgrade pods and set taint on both controllers.
Work in progress
Ready for review.

Short description about what we should do now:

Tripleo and ironic missed the ussuri-em transition deadline and meanwhile ussuri state was changed to 'extended maintenance' (see https://releases.openstack.org). So to merge Tripleo and Ironic and transition them to EM we need to do the following:

1. Move back Ussuri to 'maintained' state temporarily until we finishes the following steps
2. do tripleo && ironic final release
3. tag tripleo && ironic with ussuri-em
4. set back Ussuri state to 'extended maintenance'

deliverables/ussuri/ironic.yaml.message:
Hmmm, I see upgrade notes [1] that might indicate that this release is not really appropriate to a stable branch as it contains new (?) config entries to be set.

Are the team sure they want to release them? Can those cause issue for users if those options are not set?

Since we are far beyond the Ussuri EM deadline I'd rather not release this from ironic (and set 15.0.2 as final release from Ussuri). In that way Vendors / operators should decide themselves whether to consume the patches downstream, maybe giving more focus on the changes. What do you think?

+1: the hash is not the latest, we miss one patch ( I80d1b3e7f9e2e23ddaca640714a342b63ae3a5fa ) but that's not a problem...

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/473cb9467ccd45a28be3337b15707b29/log/tox/list-changes-results.log#2122-2143
IIRC this is more of a "should" than "must".

That's correct. It's a policy and there can be exceptions if a team / stable cores decide so. That's why I wrote down my opinion and asked back. -1 was given to highlight my question. There are cases where new config options are introduced to give a workaround for a bug, and they usually don't change default behavior as that can cause problems for operators. At least that is the best available option (in case another bugfix is not available due to different reasons).

For this particular case I feel safer to not release 15.0.3 as a 'final' release for Ussuri.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Confusing commit message because of "... and ... and ... and ...", so it's not clear to me when it cannot succeed.

The liveness and readiness probes was using a healthcheck that isn't the most suitable for it. This probe used was very intrusive and the healthcheck just return ok when the rabbit was fully booted and if was syncing table or things like that the liveness would failed and the pod would enter into a pod restart deadlock. This healthcheck is wrong as the main objective of the liveness is to check if the pod is health and running and restart it just if the pod enter in a failed state.
Usually we see test cases like "do this and verify that" or "verify that x happens after doing y". It's unclear here what was verified.

PASS: Close rabbitmq connection inside pod and verify if Liveness fail and rebooted the pod.
PASS: Readiness check pod state and verify if can ping it to check if the pod is health after get up.

Does it need to be a bridge? Could be bond0.11?

I think there are two basic cases where this could happen.

1. Bond with VLAN management network:

eno1 -> bond0 -> bond0.11

2. Bridge with VLAN management network:

eno1 -> br0 -> br0.11

this is partial configuration, the full is much more complicated, something like:

eno0 \            /--> bond0.11 --> brpxe
      +-> bond0 -+---> bond0.12 --> brmgmt
eno1 /            \--> bond0.13 --> brpub

eno2 \            
      +-> bond1 -+---> bond1.14 --> brstrg
eno3 /

and once more, this is not the basic case. this is simplified scheme describe production we use.
networks.yml or group_vars seems more appropriate.
it does not matter again. this is global for all overcloud. can be provided in the any other yaml ovveride file.

I wonder if this is the right place to define this method. Maybe  ``tacker/tests/functional/sol_v2/test_vnflcm_basic.py`` is. You can call ``show_lcmocc`` there and check the response body (setting ``expected_status`` is not required as tests will fail if a response is not 200).

This is just an example.
```
def assert_op_state_equal(self, lcmocc_id, state):
    _, body = self.show_lcmocc(lcmocc_id)
    body['operationState'] == state:
        return 
    raise Exception(f"Operation failed. state: {state}")
```
Or you can directly write the content of the above method into your tests.

This method is only used by ``test_fail_instantiate`` currently and is specific to check if `operationState` is a specific state, i.e., FAILED. Adding this kind of method will make a bloated base class.

Basically, I think we need to be cautious about extending a base class and should only add methods for a general-purpose rather than a specific purpose. We can define a method as an external module or a member method of a child class first and then move to a base class after the method becomes general in the future.

Could you tell me your opinion?

I agreed. I deleted check_lcmocc_failed method and write the check in the test case directly.
I have fixed in the patch set 11.

Isn't it possible to define these tests in a different file or a different class?

The filename is ``test_vnflcm_basic``. This is not a basic test, but error handling. In SOL003 these operations are grouped as ``VNF LCM operation occurrences`` and given a different endpoint ``{apiRoot}/vnflcm/{apiMajorVersion}/vnf_lcm_op_occs`` from the basic operations like instantiation/termination. 

IMO, we should keep a test class small as possible for future extensibility. If we allow us to implement several different test scenarios into a single class, the test class gets bigger and bigger.
